blocks.text: In Class IX, you began your exploration of real numbers and encountered irrational numbers. In this chapter, we continue our discussion on real numbers and study important properties of positive integers.
We study Euclid’s Division Algorithm and the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, which help us understand divisibility, prime factorisation, and properties of numbers.
Every composite number can be expressed as a product of primes, and this factorisation is unique apart from the order of the primes.
Using a factor tree, we can break a number step by step into its prime factors.

blocks.title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
blocks.statement: Every composite number can be expressed as a product of primes, and this factorisation is unique apart from the order.

blocks.text: A number is irrational if it cannot be written in the form p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0.

blocks.title: Proof that √2 is Irrational
steps: Then √2 = a/b where a and b are coprime.
This implies 2 divides a and b, which is a contradiction.

blocks.title: Proof that √3 is Irrational
steps: Assume √3 = a/b where a and b are coprime.
So 3 divides a and b, contradiction.

blocks.text: Every composite number has a unique prime factorisation. The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic helps in finding HCF, LCM, and proving irrationality of numbers like √2 and √3.
